abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Agriculture
            Productivity Improvement Project (APIP) were as follows:
            outcomes were unsatisfactory, sustainability was unlikely,
            the institutional development impact was modest, the Bank
            performance was unsatisfactory, and the borrower performance
            was unsatisfactory. From the implementation experience of
            the project, a number of lessons can be drawn with
            applicability in Cambodia and a wider context: (a) the
            special circumstances of Cambodia in the early 1990s i.e. a
            country whose human resource base and public sector
            apparatus had been severely damaged must be taken into
            account in any attempt to understand the rationale for
            project design and the idiosyncrasies of project
            implementation; (b) sustainability can be achieved only if
            there is ownership within the institutions and interest on
            the part of the key players; (c) in order to fill a void,
            three elements of sub-sectoral strategy were identified to
            be designed during the early years of the project and five
            were added at the Mid-term Review and these have been
            valuable in assisting the government and in encouraging an
            informed dialogue between the government and donors; (d) it
            is essential that preparatory work (e.g., base-line studies)
            and system design should be done as part of project
            preparation and that the monitoring system should function
            from the beginning of a project; (e) where components were
            implemented by Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and
            Fisheries Departments, there tended to be a
            "double" management structure and, hence, from
            early in the project emphasis was given to the
            "main-streaming" of APIP into the regular
            structure of MAFF Department; (f) complex procedures
            concerning the approval of expenditures that had already
            been agreed to in annual work plans caused significant
            delays, compounded by delays in the release of counterpart
            funds; and (g) as a result of its complexity, with nine
            components and eighteen sub-components, the IDA budget for
            supervision was consistently inadequate to include the
            required technical expertise in every supervision mission,
            and as a result, some components could not receive
            appropriate technical guidance.
